Award.AwardTitle: From Hot to Cold Jupiters: Determining The Frequency Of Orbital Migration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This work will extend and complete the precise radial velocity (RV) survey at McDonald Observatory of 500 nearby stars. The ladditional years of data collection will make it possible for the investigators to identify many extrasolar planets with long (12-15 years) orbital periods. Their main research goal is to determine the fraction of planetary systems that have undergone significant migration, including planets that are more than 5 AU from their host star, to constrain models of planetary system formation.

Broader impacts include the participation of several graduate students in the research, production of 12 StarDate radio broadcasts, and public outreach programs through the McDonald Observatory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes:

Over the course of this grant we have monitored over 250 stars in the solar neighborhood using the faciltites at McDonald Observatory. We have collected thousands of stellar spectra with the Tull Coude Spectrograph at the 2.7 m telescope to measure precise Doppler velocities. Our goal was to find giant planetary companions at large orbital separations, similar to Jupiter and Saturn in our Solar System.

Highlights of our program include: the discovery of HR 5183b, the longest period planet at a distance of 18 astronomical units from its parent star, the discovery of a planet around Aldebaran, a 12-year activity cycle of the planet host HD 219134, two Jupiter analogs orbiting HD  95872 and psi 1 Draconis B. We also published stellar activity cycles that mimicked the presence of Jupiter analogs. Some of these new planets will be excellent targets for future direct imaging attempts. 

Over the course of this grant we have produced and aired several "StarDate" radio shows to communicate our NSF-funded research to the general public. The project and the PI was also featured in an article in Astronomy magazine. Members of our team have also given numerous public talks over the years. We have also included junior members in the team, primarily undergraduate students that were trained to use the telescope and to perform their own research projects with the data collected by our survey,
